Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE: Symmetry Group-based Regularity Perception in Human and Computer Vision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Robust Intelligence (RI) Program in the Division of Information and Intelligent Systems in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, and the Perception, Action and Cognition (PAC) Program in the Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences.

This research integrates theoretical, experimental and algorithmic thrusts to construct a novel conceptual framework for predicting and understanding the full range of regularity perception, both in humans, by measuring human brain activation and behavior, and in machines, through a computational framework for adaptive symmetry detection in computer vision. The ability to detect patterns in natural scenes serves critical biological needs while posing substantial computational difficulties for machine intelligence. Research on human and computer perception of pattern regularity has primarily focused on bilateral symmetry, despite a wide variety of regular patterns beyond reflection. A unique feature of the proposed project is to use symmetry group theory as an organizing principle for the study of both human and computer perception of patterns. Symmetry group theory, instantiated by its subgroup hierarchy, provides a formal and exhaustive categorization of all regular patterns.

The project sits at an interdisciplinary nexus between computer science, psychology, neuroscience, and mathematics. The outcomes of this research could potentially transform the theory of human pattern perception and make a quantum leap in robust automatic detection of real world regularities. Because patterns are ubiquitous, this research impacts all information processing systems challenged by large digital datasets that are hard to explore manually. Its impact is strengthened further by a systemic outreach to the respective research communities through interdisciplinary workshops, publications, data sharing, classroom lectures, postdoc and student training. Applications include anomaly detection in medicine and surveillance data; mobile robot localization in man-made environments; and generic pattern indexing and retrieval.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We identified a network of visual areas that are  involved with processing symmetry in wallpaper patterns using a combination of fMRI and Steady-State Visual Evoked Potentials. This work was  published in the Journal of Neuroscience (Kohler et al., 2016.

In order to determine which of the areas identified in Kohler et al., (2016)  are directly involved in perceptual decisions about symmetry, we asked 22 participants to make rapid judgments about whether an exemplar image belonged to wallpaper group P1, or one of the four symmetry groups (P2, P3, P4, P6) that vary in the degree of rotation symmetry. We used an Event-Related Potential  (ERP) design that allowed us to perform a response-locked analysis, where the trial-to-trail variability in the behavioral response timing makes it possible to isolate neural activity in the ERP that is explicitly driving participants’ behavioral response times. Our initial sensor-space analysis of the ERP revealed strong stimulus-locked differences between P1 and rotation symmetry images, with weaker responses for lower order symmetry, replicating our previous results (Kohler et al., 2016). When we projected these data into source space, for a subset of the participants (n=15), we found that the most consistent cortical source for these stimulus-locked differences was VO1, a topographically organized visual area on the ventral surface of the brain. VO1 was also found to have strong symmetry-related responses in our previous study (Kohler et al., 2016). We then performed the response-locked analysis on the same data, and found that ERP responses in VO1 also well-correlated with behavioral response timing, suggesting that this area plays a crucial role in perceptual decisions about symmetry. Other candidate areas, like lateral occipital cortex, had weaker stimulus-locked response differences, and no evidence of a response-locked correlation with button-press timing. A manuscript is in preparation

 

Key Outcomes:  Through a combination of EEG, fMRI approaches, we have identified an extensive network of human brain areas that are selectively responsive to symmetry in textures.  By combining EEG and behavioral measurements based on reaction time in a perceptual decision task, we have been able to determine that a subset or areas that are responsive to symmetry (notably VO1 and V4 on the ventral surface of the brain) have activity in them that is predictive of the timing of behavioral responses.  It is thus this subset of areas that is most relevant to perception and suggests that other areas may feed into these areas which are then read-out for perception.
